Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Flexoelectric Effect in Ferroelectric Nanowires for High-Performance Nanogenerators

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program award is to gain fundamental understanding of the flexoelectric effect (polarization induced by inhomogeneous strain) in single-crystalline ferroelectric nanowires (NWs). The theoretical prediction of a gigantic flexoelectric enhancement of the polarization on the nanometer scale will also be tested. If true, it would make possible highly efficient nanogenerators for nanoscale mechanical energy harvesting. The research will focus mainly on BaTiO3 NWs because bulk polycrystalline BaTiO3 has the highest reported flexoelectric coefficient. Other perovskite ferroelectric NWs, such as PbTiO3 and Pb(ZrxTi1-x)O3 (PZT), will also be studied to reveal the cation contribution to flexoelectricity. The bulk of the research is to use these well-characterized NWs as a basis for state-of-the-art scanning probe microscopy studies, which will quantify the intrinsic flexoelectric coefficients and testing the prediction of flexoelectric enhancement and establish the phase and domain contributions to the flexoelectric effect. In addition, supported by experimental measurements, the nanoscale intrinsic flexoelectric coefficients and the mechanical-to-electric energy conversion efficiencies will be theoretically predicted.

This research will provide an in-depth, experimentally grounded understanding of the flexoelectric effect at the nanometer scale, which is expected to generate transformative knowledge for directing the design of nanogenerators with dramatically improved mechanical-to-electric energy conversion capability and, more generally, will establish a materials science basis for reduction in size and enhancement in performance of conventional piezoelectric and ferroelectric devices. This project will be integrated into university-wide programs to reach out to high-school students and K-12 teachers and attract students from underrepresented minorities (URM) to science, technology, engineering, and mathematics disciplines. A long-term stepwise education program will be established for instructing, mentoring, and training URM students from high school students, to college freshmen, to senior undergraduate students. This effort aims at improving the diversity of students at UW-Madison. Collaboration with the campus Research Experience for Teachers program will allow us to outreach to high school teachers who are interested in advanced nanoscience and nanotechnology and to help them create or improve science courses in their own schools. A set of comprehensive lecture notes for nanotechnology education based on the PI's new nanotechnology course will be developed and distributed online.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PI and his team completed the project for his CAREER Award CMMI-1148919, studying the flexoelectric effects of materials. This project provides comprehensive understanding of the flexoelectric effect at the nanometer scale, which generates transformative knowledge for directing the design of nanogenerators with improved mechanical-to-electric energy conversion capability. The findings have spawned new research projects that are ongoing by the PI as well as other groups.

Specifically, our accomplishments from this project include the following aspects:

1. We developed a new strategy to characterize the piezopotential distribution along the cross section of bent piezoelectric and ferroelectric nanowires with minimized artifacts and screening effect by using 3D Kelvin probe microscopy. It offers an important methodology for revealing nanoscale piezoelectric and flexoelectric properties, which are critical for directing the development and optimization of nanogenerators that effectively convert mechanical energy into electricity in the nanometer scale. Furthermore, we developed FET-AFM probe for flexoelectric coefficient measurement from nanowire structures. This development offers a new capability to precisely characterize the bending strain-related piezoelectric polarization down to the meso-scale.

2. We built a comprehensive numerical model to map the piezoelectric and flexoelectric-induced electric potential distribution on deflected NW surface. This model allows us to quantify the flexoelectric coefficient from the potential profile. This model can guide the development and optimization of piezoelectric devices using advanced nanomaterials. Moreover, we developed the decoupled finite element analysis method, which can effectively simulate both the piezoelectric and flexoelectric effects. This methodology was applied to piezoelectric zinc oxide and ferroelectric barium titanate nanowires.

3. We established a numerical model to explain the coupling effect between piezoelectric polarization and surface reactivity. The model encompasses multiple material systems, including Pb(Mg1/3Nb2/3)O3-PbTiO3, ZnO, BaTiO3 and PbTiO3 systems. We revealed a number of factors that can augment the efficacy of piezoelectric potential to induce electrochemical reactions. Through designing BaTiO3 coated TiO2 and Ni(OH)2-decorated ZnO catalysts, we experimentally demonstrated the piezoelectric polarization enhancement effect on photoelectrochemical catalyst systems.

4. We discovered the semiconducting and ferroelectric or piezoelectric polarization coupled influences on photoelectrochemical electrode performance. By developing SrTiO3/TiO2 NW core/shell structure for photoelectrochemical water splitting, we demonstrated that appropriate combination of ferroelectric polarization and charge transport in a semiconducting ferroelectric material, could be a superior solution to photoelectrochemical performance improvement instead of using insulating ferroelectric materials. This discovery generates broad application potentials for further advancing the performance in piezotronics-regulated semiconductor systems such as photovoltaic devices, sensors, light emitting diodes, and electrochemical electrodes.

5.We discovered the piezotronic enhancement from ZnO nanowire based photodetectors. We demonstrated applying piezotronic effect is an effective strategy for interface engineering to enhance the photoresponse properties. This is a new understanding of the piezotronic effect in piezoelectric semiconductor-based optoelectronic devices.

6. We developed piezotronics-regulated PEC systems with single-layered graphene as the charge collector. Up to 50% photocurrent enhancement was obtained which is by far the largest improvement ratio based on piezotronic modulation, as a result of the effective decoupling of polarization generation and charge transport. We developed a Mathematica code to produce potential profiles and energy band diagrams of sections of piezotronic semiconductor and electrochemical systems. The Mathematica code provided a quantitative guideline for predicting the implementation of the piezotronic effect in many state-of-the-art heterojunction devices to engineer the material junctions and improve their performance.

7. We fabricated a mesoporous piezoelectric polymer thin film with enhanced mechanical flexibility, tunability, and piezoelectric responses. The film was then applied to prepare nanogenerators and generated considerable electrical energy by harvesting mechanical energy from surface vibration. We extended our mechanical energy harvesting effort from ferroelectric material to triboelectric systems. We developed the first triboelectric nanogenerator using natural and renewable cellulose materials. The device produces up to ~30 V and ~90 μA electric outputs when subjected to a normal human step.

Finally, research results from this project have been disseminated to the research community and are also accessible to the general public. This project resulted in more than 23 publications in peer-reviewed journals. Research was also presented at national and international conferences. The project has made broader impacts on next-generation scientists. In terms of training students, this project has partially supported the education and training of 5 PhD students. Four undergraduate students participated in this project. A number of outreach activities including K-12 outreach have been conducted.
